Name: Solaris Zones, or Zones
Typical use: Server consolidation with workload isolation, single workload containment, hosting, dev/test/prod
Speed relative to host OS: Near native

Name: Hyper-V Server 2008 R2
Guest OS Symmetric multiprocessing avail: Yes, up to 4 VCPUs per VM
Typical use: Server consolidation, service continuity, dev/test, desktop virtualization, cloud computing
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]Wikipedia:Citation needed

Name: OpenVZ
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]Wikipedia:Citation needed

Name: Kernel-based Virtual Machine
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, other purposes
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]Wikipedia:Citation needed

Name: Linux-VServer
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation and security, server consolidation, cloud computing
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]Wikipedia:Citation needed

Name: Oracle VM Server for x86
Typical use: Server consolidation and security, enterprise and business deployment
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: Oracle VM Server for SPARC (LDoms)
Typical use: Server consolidation and security, enterprise and business deployment
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: OVPsim
Method of operation: Full system simulation with optional component virtualization
Typical use: Software development (early, embedded), advanced debug for single and multicore software, compiler and other tool development, computer architecture research, hobbyist
Speed relative to host OS: Depends on target architecture (full and slow hardware emulation for guests incompatible with host)[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]
Commercial support available: Yes, with commercial license from Imperas[17]

Name: PikeOS
Runs arbitrary OS: Yes, but modifications required as Paravirtualization is used
Typical use: Safety and security critical Embedded system.
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: ScaleMP vSMP Foundation
Guest OS Symmetric multiprocessing avail: Yes, up to 8,192 CPUs and 64 TB per VM[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]
Typical use: Server consolidation, Cloud computing

Name: Simics
Method of operation: Full system simulation of processors, MMUs, devices, disks, memories, networks, etc.
Typical use: Software development, advanced debug for single and multicore software, compiler and other tool development, computer architecture research, bug transportation, automated testing, system architecture, long-term support of safety-critical systems, early hardware availability, virtual prototyping
Speed relative to host OS: Depends on host machine and target architecture. Runs at near-native speeds for x86-on-x86 using VT-x, cross-simulation of other architectures can be faster or slower than real-time depending on how fast the target is and how big the target is (number of processors, number of target machines, and how much the simulation can be parallelized)

Name: Sun xVM Server
Method of operation: Paravirtualization and porting or hardware virtualization
Typical use: Servers, Development
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: SVISTA 2004
Typical use: Hobbyist, Developer, Business workstation

Name: Trango Virtual Processors
Method of operation: Paravirtualization and Paravirtualization or hardware virtualization
Typical use: Mob. phone, STB, routers, etc.
Speed relative to host OS: Near nativeWikipedia:Citation needed[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: User Mode Linux
Typical use: Developer (as a separate machine for a server or with X11 networking)
Speed relative to host OS: Non-significantly slower than native Wikipedia:Citation needed (all calls to kernel are proxied)[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: Open Kernel Labs
Runs arbitrary OS: Yes, (either with para-virtualization or HW virtualization)
Typical use: Mobile, embedded, security, safety critical, networking, legacy OS, etc.
Speed relative to host OS: Near native

Name: Oracle VirtualBox
Typical use: Business workstation, server consolidation, service continuity, developer, hobbyist
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: Virtual Iron 3.1
Typical use: Server consolidation, service continuity, dev/test

Name: Microsoft Virtual PC 2007
Method of operation: X86 virtualization, guest calls trapping where supported
Typical use: Hobbyist, Developer, Business workstation
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ] with virtual machine additions

Name: Windows Virtual PC
Typical use: Developer, Business workstation, support for Compatibility with Windows XP applications
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ] with virtual machine additions

Name: Microsoft Virtual PC 7 for Mac
Method of operation: Dynamic recompilation (guest calls trapping where supported)
Typical use: Hobbyist, Developer, Business workstation
Speed relative to host OS: Slow[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: Microsoft Virtual Server 2005 R2
Method of operation: X86 virtualization (guest calls trapping where supported)
Typical use: Server, server farm
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native with virtual machine additions but slower than with hypervisor due to proxied calls[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: CoWare CoWare
Supported guest OS Device driver: Yes ( Same compiled Software image as for the real device)
Method of operation: Full-system virtualization (Processor Core ISA + Hardware + External connections)
Typical use: Early embedded software development and integration (from driver to application), Multi-core software debugging and optimization
Speed relative to host OS: Depending on the system characteristics and the software itself, ranges from faster than real time to slow[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ].

Name: Virtuozzo
Typical use: Server consolidation, service continuity, disaster recovery, service providers
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: Xen
Guest OS Symmetric multiprocessing avail: Yes, v4.0.0: up to 128 VCPUs per VM
Method of operation: Paravirtualization and porting or hardware virtualization
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, other purposes. Xen powers most public cloud services and many hosting services, such as Amazon Web Services, Rackspace Hosting and Linode.
Speed relative to host OS: Up to native[19]

Name: XCP-ng
Method of operation: Paravirtualization and porting or hardware virtualization
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, desktop virtualization, public cloud services, hostings services and other purposes.
Speed relative to host OS: Up to native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: XenServer
Method of operation: Paravirtualization and porting or hardware virtualization
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, other purposes. Xen powers most public cloud services and many hosting services, such as Amazon Web Services, Rackspace Hosting and Linode.
Speed relative to host OS: Up to native[19]

Name: XtratuM
Typical use: Embedded, safety critical, secure
Speed relative to host OS: Near to native[ Wikipedia:Citation needed ]

Name: Z/VM
Guest OS Symmetric multiprocessing avail: Yes, both real and virtual (guest perceives more CPUs than installed), incl. dynamic CPU provisioning and reassignment
Method of operation: Virtualization (among first systems to provide hardware assists)
Typical use: Servers
Speed relative to host OS: Near native[10]

Name: z LPAR
Guest OS Symmetric multiprocessing avail: Yes, both real and virtual (guest perceives more CPUs than installed), incl. dynamic CPU provisioning and reassignment; up to 64 real cores
Typical use: Servers
Speed relative to host OS: Native: IBM System z machines always run with at least one LPAR
